huntYears.NOTES: One third of unit is private property. Access is limited.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This hunt unit is managed as a trophy limited entry unit for deer and elk.  There is a Landowner Association on the unit and the private property comprises about 35% of the total acreage.  This unit encompasses pine, aspen, and open sagebrush in the higher elevations and desert scrub in lower elevation wintering habitat.  The private property is posted and a GPS showing private/public property boundaries is recommended.  Even though the unit has private property, there is still 65% public land that is huntable.  Don't expect to gain access to hunt the private property.  The average buck taken is a 24 inch 4x4.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
Cellular phone coverage is spotty in the mountains on this hunt unit. Satellite phones do work in the area. A "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety can be used if you decide to camp in an area without cell phone service and do not wish to drive to reach service. Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.

Camps should be kept clean to prevent bear incidents. Food should be kept inside vehicles or bear-proof containers. Coolers are not bear-proof. Bears have gotten into camps in the past in this unit. Number and severity of bear incidents differ by year depending on weather and other food availability. Meat and garbage should be put away inside a vehicle or hung in a tree above 8 feet off the ground and 3 feet away from the trunk or any branches of the tree.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically between the hunting seasons.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, snow, wind and heat.  Be very cautious of lightning while hunting on high ridges or exposed slopes.  Early fall snow storms occur occasionally in this area.  Most years the snow will melt off within a day or two until through the first week of October.  Some years a big snowstorm will hit the beginning of October and make some roads impassable or very muddy.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 93.1~13000 (includes Bonanza/Vernal)~9800 (includes Bonanza/Vernal)~25–35~33.5~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns:
Mule deer on this unit are typically on the top of Diamond Mountain during the muzzleloader hunt. The top of Diamond Mountain is where the majority of the water and food is during the fall. After the rut, mule deer will move north to Browns Park and south to the Diamond Rim and lower elevations during the winter, depending on snow depth. The migration is mostly to either the north or south.

Scouting Tips:
Deer are pretty habitual until the rut starts. Scouting trips are recommended, especially for the muzzleloader hunt. The bigger, more mature bucks are sometimes harder to find and scouting trips are recommended if you wish to take a bigger mature buck. A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential. Scouting is most effective the last couple weeks before the hunt opens when they are more likely to stay in the same general area. Deer do have areas they like and stay in but they can move if they get spooked.

Mule deer rut:
The mule deer rut usually runs from mid-November-mid-December so it does not affect this hunt.

Recommended areas on Diamond Mountain:
Deer are found throughout much of the unit, depending on time of year. During all three hunts, deer are typically found higher in elevation and haven’t moved to their wintering habitat yet, which includes Browns Park and south of Diamond Rim. There are a lot of roads in the bottom of the draws on this unit so deer can be seen easily from vehicles.

Good public land areas to hunt include Wild Mountain, Diamond Rim, Top of Crouse Canyon, Marshall Draw, Warren Draw, Mail Draw, and Little Hole. Most of the ridges on this unit are public land and are accessible through public lands, although not always easily. Most of the public land on Diamond Mountain is BLM and DWR-owned lands.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: 65% Public land-BLM and State lands.  35% Private lands enrolled in Diamond Mountain Landowner Association.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds near this unit are managed by the US Forest Service. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the public lands including wildlife management areas. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their website.
Ashley National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/ashley/home
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Vernal and Dutch John topo maps or BLM version equivalent that shows land ownership.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service, BLM, or DWR and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. There is no off-road vehicle use allowed on DWR lands except on established roads and trails.
Ashley National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov/detail/ashley/home/?cid=STELPRDB5432815
BLM: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html Most areas are closed to off road vehicle use except on designated routes.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The boundary of this hunt unit does not include Tribal Trust Lands, but does have private land included.  There is private property on Diamond Mountain.  You should receive written permission from the landowner before hunting on private property.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Daggett and Uintah counties--Boundary begins at the Utah-Colorado state line and the Green River at Browns Park; west along this river to Gorge Creek; south along Gorge Creek to the USFS/private land boundary at the head of Davenport Draw; south along the USFS/private land boundary on the west side of Davenport Draw to the BLM boundary; south along the BLM boundary approximately one-third of a mile to the rim of Diamond Mountain; south and easterly along this rim until the rim intersects the Diamond Mountain road (Jones Hole Road); south and west on this road to the Brush Creek road; south on this road to the Island Park/Rainbow Park road; east on this road to the Dinosaur National Monument boundary; north and east on this boundary to the Utah-Colorado state line; north on this state line to the Green River. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Dutch John. Boundary questions? Call Vernal office, 435-781-9453.
